doc.title: SentinelOne (S) FQ2'26: Platform helps crest $1BR ARR
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/SentinelOne S FQ226 Platform helps crest 1B ARRSentinelOne S FQ226 Platform helps crest 1B ARR_2025-08-29

passages.text: U.S. SMID-Cap Software

SentinelOne's FQ2'26 earnings delivered its largest ARR beat vs. consensus (+1.6%) in more than a year (a time over which beats were little or even negative), although overall GAAP revenue came in largely in line (beat +$0.2MM) as some linearity and impact from less service revenue resulted in a bit less recognized. On the other hand, they raised the full year only a little (+$1.5MM) as management emphasized remaining "prudent" given ongoing macro and DOGE exposure. On the back of the revenue strength, the company was able to deliver a ~200bps beat on Non-GAAP OpM.

**Broader emerging product contribution continued to shine, accounting for~50% of** **quarterly bookings.** This continued recent trends of strong growth across the Singularity Platform. When management was asked if this was driven more by one or a few parts of the platform getting most traction, management emphasized it was really broad based.They pointed to Purple AI seeing triple-digit quarterly bookings growth YoY driven by their highest attach rate ever, and a win in the quarter with a Fortune 50 retailer who adopted cloud security as their first product. The company sees strong opportunity to upsell/cross sell off these wins outside their traditional EDR product suite, and emphasized their share of EDR continues to grow.

**Earnings included two key announcements: flex pricing, acquisition of Prompt** **Security** (private). Flex pricing has proven very popular for CrowdStrike, and even though it is brand new for SentinelOne they mentioned strong pipeline of requests for the capability and immediate demand. Prompt Security promises to help SentinelOne customers extend their EDR agent to help security and IT better monitor, govern, and control their employee's GenAI usage - a pressing need as individual adoption of non-approved vendors skyrockets and opens potential new risk pathways on the endpoint.

Our model'sARR stays roughly stable, but we lower near term margins a little given weaker guidanceApplying a 50/50~8x Price to NTM revenue multiple (down from 9x) from our Rule-of-40 regression, and our DCF model (12% WACC down from 13%, 3% terminal growth), we raise our PT to $26 and maintain our Outperform rating.

Disconnect on massive ARR beat vs. revenue roughly in line is caused primarily by linearity. Significant outperformance in this quarter is great news for ARR but deals closing later in the quarter left less revenue impact. Additionally, professional services came in lighter than expected (although the company emphasized it is a pretty small number to begin with). The guidance remains conservative given the strong Q2 performance, as management aims to be prudent, especially regarding larger deals in the pipeline (which can take less predictable time to close) and the risk around US Fed due to DOGE in H2.

Q2's strong performance was not primarily due to last quarter's deal slippage (yes, those deals closed, but were a small contributor). Management notes that deal timing changes frequently and has not observed a major shift in sentiment among mid- market companies on a macro basis. They believe the mid- market segment continues to be a source of strength for the company.

Management sees products such as vulnerability management, exposure management, ISPM, and identity as currently under- deployed. Thanks to Flex, they expect to benefit and achieve meaningful growth in these areas as customers can explore usage more easily.

Growth outside the endpoint business is on track, particularly in cloud and data segments. Although these areas are progressing well, management expects it will take a couple more years before they regularly disclose detailed performance metrics for them. They want them to reach a larger scale that would smooth out optical lumpiness of large deal contribution (or lack thereof) in a quarter.

Growth in the endpoint business has been strong, and the focus remains on scaling this segment. They are also working to expand emerging businesses where they have been dominant. When considering the remaining \(50\%\) of the market share not owned by other top modern EDR vendors, it is not limited to Fortune 500 companies but is more broadly distributed. In these areas, SentinelOne does not face some of the competitors present in the enterprise segment.

A Fortune 50 e- commerce giant is "de- platformizing," reflecting skepticism about platformization. Management believes not all customers buy into platformization since no single vendor can cover all capabilities. This customer initially adopted platformization from a leading NetSec vendor, but has since reversed course. Nevertheless, certain pockets of platform adoption may still occur. For this particular deal it was a migration to SentinelOne's cloud security offering. They are looking to follow it up possibly with endpoint solutions also migrating to SentinelOne, next.

Purple represents the first generation of Al SOC. When Athena is released, it will mark the first true platform provider with innate Al SOC capabilities, featuring agentic functions deeply integrated into the data lake and data pipeline.

A couple of other details: regarding consumption- based revenue, the committed portion is included in ARR, with additional consumption on top. SentinelOne Ventures contributes financial and cash benefits, as well as strategic alignment by providing insights into multiple markets through investments in areas such as quantum computing.
EXHIBIT 1: We expect SentinelOne's ARR growth in high-20s stabilizing to mid-to-low-20s over next couple quarters.
Source: Company reports, Bernstein estimates and analysis

EXHIBIT 2: We impute that NRR has been steady at just under \(110\%\) the last couple quarters. Our model anticipates it stays pretty flat, with only some modest improvement (rising a few 10s of bps a quarter) as we get to easy comps and have more and more backlog of new customers who are ready to expand by H2 FY26.

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, LP. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.

Our price target of \(\) 26\(is an average of DCF (12% WACC, 3% terminal growth) and 8x P / Sales (Next 5 - 8Q) comp multiple. P / Sales (Next 5 - 8Q) comp multiple is selected in the high - growth proportion of Ro40 Cloud SaaS cohort from our valuation framework analysis. We assume the current Cloud SaaS multiples regression line remains consistent for 1 + year.

Downside risks beyond the macroeconomic risks include: continued tie to cloud growth, executive talent churn and operational disruption during ramp up of replacements, execution risk in going up- market to target enterprise customers; maintaining traction in the product portfolio outside their core endpoint business, upmarket "best- of- breed" competitors moving into their managed service provider customers, platforms moving into their core business

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:
